title: Peer Tutor Status and Outcomes in Primary Mathematics
abstractText:
The award will fund a project looking at the role that tutor status plays in determining cognitive and affective outcomes during peer tutoring in primary school mathematics.

The aims and objective of this study are:

  • To develop successful pedagogical approaches in peer tutoring in mathematics for use with 10-12 year-old children.
  • To ascertain whether status of tutor influences tutoring discourse, cognitive and affective outcomes (self-esteem, social relationships and self-concept of pupils) when using reciprocal role tutoring techniques in primary school settings. A pre-post design will be employed.

This design will record changes and track outcome measures and variables that could be attributable to peer tutoring as tutoring proceeds in two mathematics topics. The first tutoring topic will be Number and Measurement, and the second will focus on Data Handling. Control groups do not form part of this study.

The study is not trying to establish that peer tutoring in mathematics is effective. Instead the proposal aims to discover whether tutor status influences outcome measures. Previous studies have not examined predictive nature of tutor status on outcome measures. The sample will be composed from 20 primary schools.
